text:
- [Instructor] We're
excited to be introducing
AWS' Customer Carbon Footprint Tool.
This new tool allows you to view
the estimated carbon footprint associated
with your usage of AWS services,
helping you to accurately assess
your organization's total carbon footprint
and track emissions reductions over time.

Customers use AWS for
many different reasons,

including increased
agility and innovation,

access to our global
infrastructure and cost savings.
But running your workloads on AWS
is also much more sustainable

than running on
on-premises infrastructure.

451 Research, part of S&P
Global Market Intelligence,

found that AWS can lower a
workload's carbon footprint
by 88% compared to the median surveyed
US enterprise data center,

and compared to European
enterprise data centers
by up to 96%, once AWS is powered
with 100% renewable energy.

Which is a target we are
on a path to meet by 2025.

However, customers who have
set carbon reduction goals
still need to accurately measure
the carbon emissions associated
with using our cloud services today.
The Customer Carbon Footprint Tool
now makes it easy for customers

by calculating the carbon
footprint of their workloads
hosted on AWS.
Estimates are calculated
using the Greenhouse Gas Protocol

and are shared in easy to
understand data visualizations.
- [Male Instructor] To access
the Customer Carbon Footprint Tool,
first log into the AWS Management Console,

then click your account
name in the top right,
and select billing dashboard.

From there, select the
cost and usage reports

in the left navigation
pane, and scroll down

to the Customer Carbon
Footprint Tool section.
you'll need a new AWS identity
and access management permission,

sustainability:get
carbon footprint summary,
to access this report.

Once you've loaded the
Customer Carbon Footprint Tool,

you'll have the option
to set the time periods
you are interested in.
Data is delivered once a month,

and you can look back
as far as January 2020.
As you set your preferred time periods,
the dashboard will refresh
with the estimated carbon emissions
generated during that period.

Within the tool, you'll
see five different sections

that provide insight into
your carbon emissions
generated from using AWS.

In green, you'll see your
estimated AWS emissions.

This is your total
combined scope one and two

carbon footprint for the
time period you've chosen

in metric tons of carbon
dioxide equivalent.

Then, based on data from
the 451 Research report

mentioned earlier we calculate
the carbon emission saved

by running your workloads on
AWS rather than on-premises.
In the next section,

you can see where your
emissions were generated.

This data's calculated
from the specific services

you use in each AWS region
and aggregated by geography.

The tool also provides a
breakdown of your emissions

by broad AWS service, based
on your usage history.

You can also review changes
in your emissions over time.

This data can be viewed either
by month, quarter or year.

In the last section,
you can view a forecast

of your future carbon emissions
over the next few years.

This chart uses your
current AWS usage patterns
and AWS' renewable energy project roadmap

to show how your carbon
emissions will change over time.
As AWS executes towards our goal of using
100% renewable power in our data centers,
which we are on a path to meet by 2025.

Over time, you'll notice
your forecast changing
as your usage changes,

and as AWS announces
new renewable projects
around the world.
The Customer Carbon Footprint Tool
adds to the suite of services

helping AWS customers
make actionable decisions
to reduce their carbon emissions.

In addition, the Well-Architected
Sustainability Pillar

provides design principles,
operational guidance,
and best practices you can use

to meet sustainability targets
for your AWS workloads.

We'll continue to work
backwards from our customers
to give you the tools, data, and guidance

you need to reduce your
environmental impact.

To learn more about AWS'
sustainability efforts,
visit AWS.amazon.com/sustainability.
